I like the way you think but actually this kind of football schools gives 
these players general lessons like math , english , historical etc. So they 
learn and play at there. But they mostly train. Hope i helped you :) see

comments.author: RuneSport

comments.text:
+Zroxor I can't speak for Crotia, of course. I don't know how it works 
there - you may be right that's a total gamble to become a football player 
there, in which case kids do need to think twice.
Here in Denmark $30m is spread out amongst schools that take in elite 
sports playing kids - to give them the funds to make a special schedul for 
those kids. And many football clubs, like my old one, also connects 
themself with a local school - paying them each year - to help their kid 
players get an education in those odd hours they're not training with the 
team.
comments.author: Dos Reis

comments.text:
+Dos Reis I agree, im not telling my opinion is right, just speaking from 
my experience so far :) still in my 20s...
For the education of footballers, i dont know where are you from but in my 
region (Croatia and neighbourhood countries) it really sucks.
comments.author: Zroxor

comments.text:
+Zroxor Oh, you mean talents in general? Of course they have school on the 
side. I played for a semi-pro team and even THEY had a school connected to 
their program. You don't truly think clubs are just shitting on the kids, 
do you? I'd reckon that if you're a talent at a big club you're probably 
getting a better education than most other people.
No - this was actually just her "trying something new with her life". I'll 
never argue with you that time makes perfect, but it just isn't as black 
and white as you perceive it - you can still be great no matter what.
comments.author: Dos Reis

comments.text:
+Dos Reis omg stop repeating about "one year". To be at the level these 
kids are you have to train for years, this is just one of the chances they 
will take to become professionals so they sacrifice all the years they 
trained instead studying. The scientist you mentioned was probably in 
similar field of knowledge before that and everything she learned before 
that lead to become great in psy science. You build knowledge on knowledge.
comments.author: Zroxor

comments.text:
+Zroxor One of the most highly rated cognitive scientists we have in my 
country is somewhere in the late 60's - however, she didn't decide on the 
field of psychology till she was 40-something. 
To say that you can't become great at your chosen field because you skipped 
one year of school is nonsense.
comments.author: Dos Reis

comments.text:
+Zroxor The thing is with this is that they're all great footballers, but 
the scouts only pick the best player. 100 talented footballers, but one 
amazing one. Sadly yes they do miss a year of school but i don't think it 
will ruin their whole life.
comments.author: presmokan

comments.text:
+Dos Reis well yea, its not ruined but they all have a big setback in 
education. And for any skill you want to be good at in life it takes long 
time, it starts with general education and then speciality in some field. I 
think they should be smart and always have a backup plan, not everyone from 
this group are good for football, they just dont know it yet, Maybe some of 
them will be a great doctor, scientist etc.
comments.author: Zroxor

(Australian Football League) .. its played no where else in the world, its 
like using a rugby ball, but you kick it with you foot, hand ball, but 
there are 4 posts, (goals in between). SO we call "football" soccer. So its 
less confusing :)

top_comment.text:
For all the people scared of never getting to high level because they are 
too ''old'', i started playing september 2014 I was 15 and I was playing in 
an academy where I payed for my trainings and I immediately got spotted by 
the trainer of a team called CIF (plays against benfica, porto, sporting, 
belenenses etc... at U-17 level.) so it's never too late, just don't do 
things that aren't healthy and train a lot!﻿
top_comment.author: Mattia Camossi

comments.text: +arber beqa Glad to help bro, hopefully i'll see you on the pitch one day :)
comments.author: Mattia Camossi

comments.text: thnx mate you made my night
comments.author: arber beqa

comments.text:
+arber beqa Yea man im from 99' and it was my first year playing football 
in an academy (still is) when they spotted me and got me in the team.
The whole concept of CIF is to build players for the big teams to buy since 
we have no professional team in the Liga 1 (first portuguese league) but we 
are known as one of the best teams in the U-17 bracket.
Scouts really like players that are strong and fast, simply because if you 
are fit it means you care about your good shape, and technique is something 
that can be tought.
If you are healthy and are sure that your dream is to become a professional 
football player, go for it! If you are sure you could be spotted by scouts, 
I would recommend starting on an academy where u have to pay (it's usually 
not a lot) and you will get spotted quickly. If you are not very confident 
about your strenght and agility with the ball, maybe you should start by 
training by yourself in the street somewhere where u can practice to master 
the ball (there are a lot of guides on youtube of exercises to help you 
with ball control). 
I hope I helped somehow, and it's never too late to start!
comments.author: Mattia Camossi

comments.text:
+Mattia Camossi so that means you're a 99' guy?the first time ever to play 
football in an academy ?
I've trained in a gym for nearly 5-6 months on and off but I am more 
stronger than any other player physically and I wouldn't mind running at 
7am or anything it can make my dream come true no matter what
but I'm 16(turned last month) and I'm afraid that no scout is going to come 
oh and do you get paid from CIF?
sorry for the overwhelming questions but it seems you to be the one that 
walked in my shoes
love u bro
comments.author: arber beqa

captions.text: 44 players from 33 countries.

You're here to hopefully win a place at the
Nike Academy.

Every day we train with intensity, speed and
desire.
The level is high.
You can see it from the pace they're able to maintain throughout the match
and from the passing technique.
It will be hard work for you.

I expect you to express yourselves as best
you can.
To give everything you can.

And not go away saying I should have done
better.

You've got to be in love with the game. That's
the key to it for me.

I've always loved beautiful football, looking
after the ball, like we do in Peru.
And that's what I love.
Football is my passion.

Being a 16 year old at England's training
ground.
It's a dream.
These boys have just got to enjoy themselves as much as they can.
Listen to what the coaches are saying,
how they can develop and improve and express themselves.
It's a great atmosphere
What better place than St.George's.
Passing has to be good.
In tight areas you've got to make quick decisions.

Your touch has go to be good. Your passes 
have got to be crisp and accurate.

You can see a footballer, you can see the
way he moves.

His balance, his technical 
ability on the ball.
How he passes the ball.

Can he manipulate the ball, can he move the
ball side to side and juggle it.

Does he individually express himself but also
as a team player?

That trick on the ball, that little flair
needs to be for the team, not just for himself.
A few players stick out quite early.
He talks doesn't he, the big fella.
Talking, communication isn't bad.
Pass quicker, quicker.
The language could be a little bit of a problem,
but football's a world game.
They'll do their talking on the pitch.

Off the field their social and psychological
aspects are going to play a big role.
It's all about hard work and sacrifice.
Keep going and first of all, believe in yourself.
Don't forget to play with a smile,
because football first is to enjoy.
Today is a new day.
Now this is a chance for you to start expressing yourself in competitive football.
We're always looking for the same thing.

It's football intelligence, to show that they
understand the game.

When to run, when to stand still, when to
pass, when to take someone on,
and how to defend properly as well.
You so so heavily rely on your team-mates.
You need to be a team player.

Fitness in any sport, especially in professional
football,

is paramount to helping you become a better
player.
You may have the technical and tactical ability,
but if you aren't physically strong

and have those attributes then it's going
to be really hard for you to succeed at the
top level.
Once we've assessed them in all these areas,

we've got a really good idea about their physical
performance levels.
It's been a very long day.

Everybody is tired so now it's up to the 
mental strength to keep working hard.

Their whole effort now for the next 12 or
14 hours
until we congregate again and start training

has got to be focussed around match preparation
for tomorrow morning.

It's called the chance for a reason. It is
their chance tomorrow afternoon.

We're going to get ready for the 11s v 11s
against the academy.

I'm a little bit nervous but I'm fit and ready
to go today. If there's anyone coming for

my positive then I'm prepared to work even
harder.

I'm actually at this point where I can change
my life right now.

It's a chance to start your professional career.
Everything could go your way from this day forwards.
You need to be yourself.

If you're good at passing short, you pass
short.
If you're good at blocking, you block.
Good luck, enjoy the afternoon.

He's done well there the big fella he's done
well.

That individual skill is good but that's only
a small segment of the cake.
His understanding of the game.

I think he's brave and he's got a presence
about him.
Go on Dylan!
What a catch that was by the way.

We're trying to play for their places, so
I thought we did quite well.
Great take.
Well done.
What a good ball that is.
You're in trouble now.
You're in trouble now.
It was a good experience but it was hard.

He's comfortable on the ball, and I also think
you can sit him as a holding midfield player.
With that physique, he can only get better.
Well done, well played.

Probably the outstanding player of the weekend,
unless I'm wrong would be Dylan.
The number 1, he's your goalkeeper.

The way he comes and takes the cross, he's
two footed.

He's 6 foot 3 and he's only 17. He attacks
the ball well.
I see lots in him that you can develop.
Covas from Brasil.
I like this kid.
He was calm and he picked a pass out.
He was the best player on show yesterday.
All the way from South Africa, Waylan Rooi.

I just stood up, I didn't know what to do.
I didn't know where to walk.
It is the best feeling ever.
1 Joel Drommel from Holland.
Number 26 Dylan Byrns.

It's going to amazingly change and I'm going
to grow a lot as a person being away from
my family and friends.
Shores closer to home, Aiden Austin.

It shows what training hard and working hard
can bring. Train hard, play hard.
Number 8, from Brasil, Bruno Covas.
Well done Bruno.
Hello my Darling.
I was the last name they called out. I thought I wasn't going to make it.
Amazing.
I've not realised what just happened yet.

title: Nike Chance: What Are Scouts Looking For?
